hero.title: From an 8-Hour Grind to a 37-Minute Flow
hero.subtitle: Visualizing the impact of process engineering on a massive national project.

challenge.title: The Challenge: A Nationwide Bottleneck
challenge.description: The task was to digitize 1,000 unique AT&T stores for a new product launch. The core problem? Our team was using SolidWorks, a tool built for product design, to model the unique architecture of each retail store from scratch. This created a massive bottleneck.

solution.title: The Solution: A Two-Step Breakthrough
solution.description: Through a series of collaborative workshops and user feedback sessions, our team designed a new system. I then led the effort to refine and optimize this workflow to achieve maximum efficiency.

impact.title: The Impact: Massive Savings & Personal Contribution

sections.title: 1. Understanding the User: Stakeholder Interviews
sections.description: To truly understand the bottleneck, I conducted qualitative interviews with 3 draftsmen (the end-users), 2 senior designers, and the project manager. My goal was to identify pain points, constraints, and opportunities. The research yielded three key findings:

findings.title: Finding 1: Repetitive Manual Labor
findings.description: Users were mentally fatigued from redrawing the same standard components for every single store, which also introduced a high risk of human error.

findings.title: Finding 2: Lack of Standardization
findings.description: Without a central library, drawings were inconsistent across the team, leading to downstream errors in manufacturing and installation.

findings.title: Finding 3: Underutilized Tool Capabilities
findings.description: The team knew SolidWorks could do more, but the existing process didn't support powerful features like templating and automation.

sections.title: 2. Visualizing the Friction: Current-State Workflow Analysis
sections.description: Based on the interviews, I mapped the "as-is" workflow. This visual artifact was critical for showing stakeholders exactly where and how time was being lost. The process was linear, manual, and had no feedback loops until the very end.

steps.title: Receive Survey
steps.description: Get raw data and photos from field surveyors.

steps.title: Interpret Data
steps.description: Manually interpret measurements and sketch a plan.

steps.title: Model from Scratch
steps.description: Draw every wall, window, and fixture line by line.

steps.title: Manual Review
steps.description: Peer review often revealed errors, forcing a restart.

sections.title: 3. The Solution: A System-Level Redesign
sections.description: The research made it clear that a simple fix wasn't enough; we needed a new system. I facilitated brainstorming sessions that led to a component-based design system within SolidWorks. This shifted the team's effort from repetitive drawing to strategic assembly.

contribution.title: My Contribution: How I Optimized the System
contribution.description: With the new system in place, I focused on refining the workflow through structured UX principles.

cards.title: User Behavior Analysis
cards.description: By analyzing how the team interacted with the survey data and software, I identified key patterns and heuristics that allowed us to pre-select the right templates, eliminating discovery time.

cards.title: Solution Design & Iteration
cards.description: I worked deeply within SolidWorks to design and prototype new workflows, creating reusable components and automation scripts that directly addressed the pain points uncovered during research.

cards.title: Continuous Optimization
cards.description: I treated every completed store as a data point, constantly measuring time and looking for micro-inefficiencies. This iterative approach allowed me to continuously refine the process without sacrificing quality.
